prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: the CE of HD62623 at band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HD62623 CE study: 1- dust distribution and mass 2- size 3 compare to Band 3, near and mid IR

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a single continuum imaging of HD62623. Low resolution at ALMA is sufficient to image the dust structure i

Our observations with VLTI (AMBER and MIDI) and our radiative transfer modeling of the Interferometric and Photometric observables shows an inner rim of the dusty componment at about 0.004-0.006 as, with an extension of at least 0.25 as (constrained by our models), therefore a spatial resolution of 0.036 with ALMA will allow us to probe the dusty structure of the circumstellar environment adding more constraints to our models. Moreover the programmed (French GTO) VLTI/SPHERE observations will allow us to study these objects at the same spatial resolution at different wavelenght allowing us besides the scientific interest to produce a composite image using ALMA, VLTI, and SHPERE observations.

For HD62623 an estimation of the flux was derived from the SED with a value of 0.5 Jy by adjusting it to the ALMA beam we have a flux density beam of 10 mJy. A S/N of 100 increasing our confidence in studying the dust distribution. Our choice of Band 7 is done taking two factors: the study of the circumstellar environment of these objects in two different bands (3 and 7) in order to constrain the extension and dust structure and the high spatial resolution is needed to achieve our goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: the CE of HD87643 at band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HD87643 CE study: 1- dust distribution and mass 2- size 3 compare to Band 3, near and mid IR

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: we request a single continuum imaging with standard setting. the low resolution at ALMA is sufficienf to image the dust structure of HD87643.

with AMBER and MIDI observations we estimate that the extension of the disk is between 0.1 as and 1. therefore in order to confirm and measure the extension of the disk we ask for a resolution of 0.1.

In the case of HD87643 the object shows an extreme IR excess. the flux was derived from the SED and have an estimated value of 70 Jy by adjunsting it to the ALMA beam size we estimate a flux density of 0.7 Jy. we request a S/N of 100 but since it is a bright object the objective is accompliched with an S/N of 5000. our choise of Band 7 is partialy based on our objective to get high spatial resolution that we will be able to compare and complete to VLT/SHPERE observation and to complete the view of the object obtained by VLTI/AMBER and MIDI observation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: the CE of HD45677 at band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HD45677 CE study: 1- dust distribution and mass 2- size 3 compare to Band 3, near and mid IR

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: we request a single continuum imaging of HD45677 with standard settings. the lowest spectral resolution at ALMA (128 chanels) is sufficient to image the dust structure.

KECK and VLTI/PIONIER observation shows a skewed disk with an inner rim of the dusty circumstellar environment at 4 mas. VLTI/MIDI (in analysis phase) are public in the archive and our first analysis of these data confirm the size obtained by the previous observations but also shows a flattened extended dusty disk with a lower limit of its extension of 300 mas. Therefore we ask for a resolution of 36 mas allowing us to probe the dusty disk and obtain a clearer view on the physics behind the B[e] phenomenon. Coupling all data available from VLTI and SPHERE we will be able to study more carefully these objects using radiative transfer models.

For HD45677 an estimation of the flux was derived from the SED with value of about 0.5 Jy adjusting it to the ALMA beam size we have a flux density of 7 mJy. A S/N of 100 is required but the achieved one is about 102. Our choice of band 3 and 7 is based on both the study of the dusty structure in different bands and wavelenghts (by combining VLTI and SPHERE data) and the spectral resoulution needed to achieve our goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: The CE of HD62623 at band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HD62623 CE study: 1- dust distribution and mass 2- size 3 compare to Band 7, near and mid IR

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a single continuum imaging of HD62623. Low resolution at ALMA is sufficient to image the dust structure i

Our observations with VLTI (AMBER and MIDI) and our radiative transfer modeling of the Interferometric and Photometric observables shows an inner rim of the dusty componment at about 0.004-0.006 as, with an extension of at least 0.25 as (constrained by our models), therefore a spatial resolution of 0.085 as with ALMA will allow us to probe the dusty structure of the circumstellar environment adding more constraints to our models. Moreover the programmed (French GTO) VLTI/SPHERE observations will allow us to study these objects at the same spatial resolution at different wavelenght allowing us besides the scientific interest to produce a composite image using ALMA, VLTI, and SHPERE observations.

For HD62623 an estimation of the flux was derived from the SED with a value of 0.1 Jy, adapting it to the ALMA beam size we obtaine a flux density of 10 mJy . A S/N of 100 is required but the achieved one is about 152. Our choice of Band 3 is done taking two factors: the study of the circumstellar environment of these objects in two different bands (3 and 7) in order to better constrain the extension and dust structure and the high spatial resolution is needed to achieve our goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: The CE of HD87643 at band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HD87643 CE study: 1- dust distribution and mass 2- size 3 compare to Band 7, near and mid IR

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: we request a single continuum imaging with standard setting. the low resolution at ALMA is sufficienf to image the dust structure of HD87643.

with AMBER and MIDI observations we estimate that the extension of the disk is between 0.1 as and 1. therefore in order to confirm and measure the extension of the disk we ask for a resolution of 0.1.

In the case of HD87643 the object shows an extreme IR excess. the flux was derived from the SED and have an estimated value of 70 Jy adapting it to the ALMA beam size we have a flux density of 0.7 Jy. we request a S/N of 100 but since it is a bright object the objective is accompliched with an S/N of 10000. our choise of Band 7 is partialy based on our objective to get high spatial resolution that we will be able to compare and complete to VLT/SHPERE observation and to complete the view of the object obtained by VLTI/AMBER and MIDI observation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: The CE of HD45677 at band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HD45677 CE study: 1- dust distribution and mass 2- size 3 compare to Band 7, near and mid IR

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: we request a single continuum imaging of HD45677 with standard settings. the lowest spectral resolution at ALMA (128 chanels) is sufficient to image the dust structure.

KECK and VLTI/PIONIER observation shows a skewed disk with an inner rim of the dusty circumstellar environment at 4 mas. VLTI/MIDI (in analysis phase) are public in the archive and our first analysis of these data confirm the size obtained by the previous observations but also shows a flattened extended dusty disk with a lower limit of its extension of 300 mas. Therefore we ask for a resolution of 85 mas allowing us to probe the dusty disk and obtain a clearer view on the physics behind the B[e] phenomenon. Coupling all data available from VLTI and SPHERE we will be able to study more carefully these objects using radiative transfer models.

For HD45677 an estimation of the flux was derived from the SED with value of about 0.1 Jy by adapting it to the ALMA beam size we have a flux density of 8 mJy. A S/N of 100 is required but the achieved one is about 150. Our choice of band 3 and 7 is based on both the study of the dusty structure at different bands and wavelenghts (by combining the VLTI and SPHERE data) and the spectral resoulution is needed to achieve our goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Supergiant B[e] stars are hot and luminous objects surrounded by gaseous and dusty circumstellar environment (CE) that formation, evolutionary status, geometry and kinematics are still highly debated. HD62623, HD45677 and HD87643 are one of the brightest of this type. They were observed with VLTI, showing that hot dust resides in the inner regions, in a form of an inner rim. We constrained with VLTI data the sizes in near and mid IR, the dust distribution as well as the gas kinematics of these CE. However, the total weight of dust around these stars remain to be measured. An extension of the observations to sub-mm with ALMA are needed in order to fully constrain the dust component in size, mass, and dust distribution. Additional infrared and visible data will be acquired within the VLT/SPHERE instrument Guaranteed Time Observations (GTO). A SPHERE/VLTI/ALMA view will provide us with an unique set of multiwavelength datasets on these stars at similar angular resolutions, giving us an exquisite view of these enigmatic systems. All observations will be modeled using state-of-the-art radiative transfer codes allowing us to get the dust and gaz mass around these objects.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
